messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba care question
messages.msgSnippet: Well, HMMMPHHH!!  After your dipso performance on another channel meintinkit you are the pot calling the kettle black!!! Dipso?  Wakarimasuka?? Barry Thomas
messages.messageBody:
Well, HMMMPHHH!! After your dipso performance on another channel meintinkit you
are the pot calling the kettle black!!!

Dipso? Wakarimasuka??

Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia - YES!! - THE Melbourne recently announced as a place of
devoted interest by a heavily head-clothed anonymous purveyor of frightening
experiences...)

----- Original Message -----
From: "nihontochicken" <rick@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, September 11, 2005 9:31 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba care question


Hey, Barry, you old perv! Oops, I mean, old sword master. Hahahaha!
Yeah, Yumoto's text is where I likely got the idea, thought I'd
embellish with all the various English spellings that yield similar
pronunciations. I have a question re the use of "ae" as in
"koshirae". Should this be pronounced "koh-shee-rah-eh"? I swear I
hear people say something like "koh-shee-ray", but I never saw a
unique pronunciation for the "ae" conjunction such as there is for the
"ai" and "ei" combinations. Let me know what you think, Barry, as
soon as you sober up enough to focus on the keyboard (try to ignore
that splitting headache from overimbibing that crappy Oz wine).
HAHAHAHAHAHA!!!

NC ;o)

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Barry Thomas" <warlord@i...> wrote:
> Chicken - how lovely to see you at work again...
>
> I always remember John Yumoto's simple little pronunciation guide in
his "The
> Samurai Sword - A Handbook". It always stood me in good stead.
Beyond that,
> Japanese is a nightmare!!! Thank The Gods that Nihonto is a study
worth a
> lifetime's perseverance...
>
> Regards,
>
> Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba care question
messages.msgSnippet: Hi NC, Many thanks Mark ... From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of nihontochicken Sent: Saturday, September 10,
messages.messageBody:
Hi NC,
Many thanks
Mark

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of nihontochicken
Sent: Saturday, September 10, 2005 12:25 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba care question


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Mark Jaillet" <mjaillet@n...> wrote:
> On a slightly serious note, are any of you aware of a book that
will tell
> how to actually pronounce nihonto related words? Or anywhere's on
the web?

Vowels are fairly simple, as follows:

"a" = "ah" as in bob, got, malt, paw, shawl, taught, thought.
"e" = "eh" as in bed, get, melt, peg, shell, threat.
"i" = "ee" as in bead, greet, me, pea, she, think.
"o" = "oh" as in bode, goat, mow, pour, sew, though.
"u" = "oo" as in boot, goof, moot, new, pool, sue, shoe, suit, through.
"ai" = "uy" as in bite, buy, eye, height, my, pie, rye, sign, thigh.
"ei" = "ay" as in bait, bay, gate, may, pail, shale, they.

"g" is always hard, as in "get", never soft, as in "germ".

There are some trickier parts, like "ko" + "katana" = "kogatana", and
"Matsushita" is pronounced "Mat-soosh-ta" (no shit, er, "sheet"!), but
the above general rules will get you through 90%+ of the battle.
Actually quite simple - look again at the various English spellings
that yield the same sound, depending on the word. Note that in
English, for instance, "dead" is not pronounced the same as "meat".
Many English pronunciations have to be individually learned, unlike
most Japanese words. Good fortune!

NC

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba care question
messages.msgSnippet: Chicken - how lovely to see you at work again... I always remember John Yumoto s simple little pronunciation guide in his The Samurai Sword - A Handbook .  It
messages.messageBody:
Chicken - how lovely to see you at work again...

I always remember John Yumoto's simple little pronunciation guide in his "The
Samurai Sword - A Handbook". It always stood me in good stead. Beyond that,
Japanese is a nightmare!!! Thank The Gods that Nihonto is a study worth a
lifetime's perseverance...

Regards,

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba care question
messages.msgSnippet: I m telling you,  you guys are a wealth of information to a newbie like me. O.K. then, Bar-B-Q? Check. Motor oil? Check. Bucket of acid? Check. Sand blaster?
messages.messageBody:
I'm telling you, you guys are a wealth of information to a "newbie" like
me. O.K. then, Bar-B-Q? Check. Motor oil? Check. Bucket of acid? Check. Sand
blaster? Check. And lots not forget the soft cloth, check. LOL

On a slightly serious note, are any of you aware of a book that will tell
how to actually pronounce nihonto related words? Or anywhere's on the web?

Thanks, Mark

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Richard Turner
Sent: Friday, September 09, 2005 8:53 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba care question


how about an acid dip, followed by vigorous rubbing metal polish, then
heated with an oxy torch, followed by sand blasting, then chroming, then
a light buff with a soft cloth.

Just like new :-)

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba care question
messages.msgSnippet: Curran - Boy, you are getting specific here. When I think about these concerns I sometimes wonder about us modern concervators. I think we think too much. We
messages.messageBody:
Curran -

Boy, you are getting specific here. When I think about these concerns I sometimes wonder about us modern concervators. I think we "think" too much. We know what should "not" be done to iron tsuba and as for what "should be done," well, I think it is just common sense to "handle" them to enhance their "aging" and otherwise, let them age without making such a fuss over them. Kinko fittings require more care than iron but iron tsuba love gentle handling. Again, common sense prevails.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Curran Campbell
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com ; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, September 07, 2005 2:18 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Tsuba care question


List-

Between intervals of carrying old iron tsuba in the
back jeans pocket to give them a slow polish, it has
been traditionally advised to give them a rub with
flannel. Over lots and lots of time, the flannel thing
works... very slowly.

_My main question_: what are the pros and cons of
using non-dyed (aka homespun) denim /instead of
flannel/ to rub the faces of the tsuba?

_Secondary question_: In jeans pocket, it seems the
mimi takes on too much polish while the face gets only
slightly polished. What are the opinions of aesthetic
about this? Should degree of Mimi polish and face
polish be equal, or would Hagihara and other Japanese
authorities recommend more polish on the mimi and less
wear on the face especially the seppa dai area, as
would happen to a mounted tsuba over time as it rubbed
against the silk/cotton of its owner's kimono?

Curran


__________________________________________________

against the silk/cotton of its owner's kimono?
